author: linoscope
content:
Hi ePBS experts! I am increasingly convinced that ePBS is the best path for slot restructuring, and that losing it to risks around the in-protocol auction/payment part (e.g., free option problem) would be a net loss for Ethereum. So I‚Äôve drafted a variant that drops the in-protocol auction while keeping the execution/aggregation pipelining and CL-EL split benefits. The tradeoff is we lose much of the blob-bandwidth boost via dual-deadline PTCs (but likely necessary if we want to truly address the free option issue, as both free option and blob scaling stems from the same commit-reveal timing structure). I believe offering multiple variants only increases the likelihood of ePBS landing, and since the heavy lifting is already done, alternatives like this are mostly subtractive changes to the specs.

Draft write-up: https://hackmd.io/@linoscope/pipelining-only-epbs
Draft consensus-specs PR: https://github.com/linoscope/consensus-specs/pull/2

Let me know what you all think, all feedback welcome! üôè

author: potuz
content: You're conflating two things here: the cause of the free option problem according to numbers by flashbots crowd is the dual PTC distance and has nothing to do with trustless payments. So relying or not on MEV boost is completely an orthogonal issue to solving that difference. You could easily remove that dual PTC deadline and keep trusted payments and not have a free option, or you could easily remove trusted payments and keep the dual PTC deadline and have free option but gain some simplicity in protocol. These two issues are completely independent.

author: 0xunclebill
content:
during the Holesky incident, a bad payload was attested to by the majority of the network because of el config issues. If we had payload block separation, would this have broken the network as badly as it did?

Thinking out loud here, attesters would attest to the consensus block at slot N. the builder would then reveal the bad payload, the ptc would attest to its timeliness and then in the next slot the bad validators would have still attested that the payload at slot N - 1 was valid and we'd still have broken the network. is that correct?

author: fradamt
content: Yes, separation won't help with a majority of the network thinking an invalid payload is valid. It would help contain the blast radius of the same case, but with a large minority instead of a majority, and would help with any kind of block production bugs that don't affect validation
